summary:
Welcome to the first edition of **Pony Foo Weekly!**

Pony Foo Weekly is a newsletter discussing interesting and trending topics around the web platform. It comes out every thursday. You can learn more at [ponyfoo.com/weekly](https://ponyfoo.com/weekly).

sections.title: How to Deploy Software
sections.description:
Zach gives a thorough -- no-frills -- deep dive into the world of deploying software.  
_Block off a couple hours in your calendar and give this a read!_

sections.title: How to Level-up as a Developer
sections.description: A Facebook engineer goes deep into what matters in moving forward in your career as a Software Engineer.

sections.title: Server-side Rendering with React, Node and Express
sections.description: It's no secret I'm a big proponent of server-side rendering. Here's an excellent guide to server-side rendering when it comes to Node.js and React.

sections.title: Tumblr Performance Case Study
sections.description: Lately, Sam has analyzed the performance for half a dozen sites and providing detailed -- actionable -- feedback on how the situation could be improved. Keep an eye out for his case studies.

sections.title: ES6 Overview in 350 Bullet Points
sections.description:
Playing catch up with the latest and greatest in JavaScript? Read through this article where you can quickly learn about every feature in ES6. Note that there's also [a series of articles on ES6](https://ponyfoo.com/articles/tagged/es6-in-depth "ES6 in Depth") that go more in depth if that's your cup of tea.

When you're done, maybe also [learn about ES2016](https://ponyfoo.com/articles/es2016-features-and-ecmascript-as-a-living-standard "ES2016 Features & ECMAScript as a Living Standard").

sections.title: Art and Math and Science, Oh My!
sections.description: Amy wrote a brilliant piece on Medium about her passions: art and science. It's a very inspirational piece and I don't want to spoil it for you _-- go read it!_

sections.title: Low Poly Tree Generator
sections.description: It doesn't get much more inspirational than this polygon tree generator. Karim is always sharing this kind of stuff on CodePen, so you might want to [visit his profile](http://codepen.io/Yakudoo/) once in a while for a dose of web-based inspiration.

sections.title: Build the Virtual Reality Web with A-Frame
sections.description:
Mozilla just released [`A-Frame`](https://hacks.mozilla.org/2016/03/build-the-virtual-reality-web-with-a-frame/ "Building blocks for the
virtual reality web"), which allows you to create **3D and VR experiences** on the Web. It looks pretty A-Mazing.

sections.title: GPU rendering in Servo with WebRender
sections.description:
Mozilla again, this time with a talk about Servo -- their next-generation browser engine in the works. This highly technical talk describes how WebRender can deliver high performance graphics even in the most bloated animation scenarios.

> We've essentially removed painting as a bottleneck in Servo.
  
<sub>The talk starts at 1:50.</sub>

sections.text: I've been meaning to learn more about web animations. Particularly, I was interested in learning the fundamentals of what makes a *good animation* (tm). [I asked on Twitter](https://twitter.com/nzgb/status/702692180670992384) and I got several links to great articles on animating content for the web.

sections.title: Animation Principles for the Web
sections.description:
Disney's 12 basic principles of animation applied to CSS with beautiful examples and transition animations.  
If you only have to pick one article about CSS animation -- make it this one!

sections.title: The Importance of Context-Shifting in UX Patterns
sections.description:
Sarah underpins the importance of making context changes more clear through the use of transition animations.  
You may also want to read [About Face (book)](http://amzn.to/1SD0KXQ), if you're interested in learning more about UX and generally treating "users" as if they were humans.

sections.title: Icon Animations Powered by mo.js
sections.description: A tutorial about a powerful animations library. While I wouldn't be particularly fond of using a library for this type of feature, the article positively brims with ideas. Check out [the demos](http://tympanus.net/Development/Animocons/ "Animated Icons with mo.js").

sections.title: What's New in jQuery 3
sections.description: jQuery 3 is here and -- although it didn't change a whole lot -- there's enough changes to the API that you might want to take a glance at this article, to cover your ground.

sections.title: Babel's Architectural Roadmap
sections.description: Amjad sheds some light into what Babel core team members are thinking in terms of the future of Babel's internal architecture.

sections.title: domenic/especially
sections.description: Abstract operations and other functions drawn from the ECMAScript specification.
